issues.issue: Depends on T32.G3.01 (same grade) - should be reordered or dependency removed
issues.recommendation: Reorder skills: G3.02 should come after G3.01 in the grade sequence, or remove dependency if not essential

issues.issue: Depends on T32.G3.02 (same grade, later skill)
issues.recommendation: Valid progression within grade if ordered correctly

issues.issue: Depends on T32.G3.02 (same grade, earlier skill) and T32.G2.05 (grade-1)
issues.recommendation: Valid dependency structure

issues.issue: Depends on T32.G3.01 (grade-1) and T32.G2.03 (grade-2) - exceeds X-2 rule
issues.recommendation: VIOLATION: T32.G2.03 is from Grade 2, but this is Grade 4. Should only depend on G3 and G4 skills. Remove G2.03 dependency or add intermediate G3 skill.

issues.issue: Depends on T32.G3.02 (grade-1) and T32.G2.01 (grade-2) - exceeds X-2 rule
issues.recommendation: VIOLATION: T32.G2.01 is from Grade 2, but this is Grade 4. Remove G2.01 dependency or add intermediate skill.

issues.issue: Depends on T32.G1.01 (grade-4 back) - severe X-2 violation
issues.recommendation: CRITICAL VIOLATION: G1.01 is 4 grades back. Replace with G3 or G4 PII skill, or remove if covered by G5.02

issues.issue: Depends on T32.G5.06 (grade-1) but also references 'G6 cipher exploration' which should be self-referential
issues.recommendation: T10.G4.01 is grade-2 back (acceptable), but verify progression is clear

issues.issue: Dependencies span too wide (G5.01, G5.02, G6.02)
issues.recommendation: T32.G5.01 and G5.02 are grade-2 back - at the edge of acceptable. Consider consolidating through G6 skill.

issues.issue: Depends on T24.G6.01 which is grade-2 back from G8
issues.recommendation: T24.G6.01 is acceptable (grade-2), but having 8 dependencies is excessive. Consider consolidating.

issues.issue: Covers FIVE different attack types (malware, phishing, DoS, MitM, SQL injection) in one skill
issues.recommendation: SPLIT into: (1) T32.G6.01.01 - Identify common malware types, (2) T32.G6.01.02 - Analyze phishing attacks, (3) T32.G6.01.03 - Understand network attacks (DoS, MitM), (4) T32.G6.01.04 - Recognize database vulnerabilities (SQL injection). Too complex for single skill.

issues.issue: Covers four distinct social engineering tactics (phishing, pretexting, baiting, tailgating)
issues.recommendation: SPLIT into: (1) T32.G5.01.01 - Analyze digital social engineering (phishing, pretexting, baiting), (2) T32.G5.01.02 - Recognize physical security risks (tailgating, shoulder surfing)

issues.issue: Comprehensive audit covering security AND ethics across multiple AI topics - too broad
issues.recommendation: SPLIT into: (1) T32.G8.03.01 - Audit AI projects for security vulnerabilities, (2) T32.G8.03.02 - Audit AI projects for ethical concerns

issues.issue: Implements three distinct security features (password length check, password masking, rate limiting) in one skill
issues.recommendation: Consider splitting or ensure adequate time allocation. Could be: (1) T32.G6.02.01 - Validate password strength, (2) T32.G6.02.02 - Implement login security controls

issues.issue: Shows complex password with symbols (C@t!2o#3) to kindergarteners - too advanced
issues.recommendation: Simplify to picture-based comparison: short password (3 dots) vs long password (10 dots). Save symbol complexity for G1-G2.

issues.issue: Requires reading comprehension of 'urgent language, misspellings' which may be too advanced for Grade 1
issues.recommendation: Focus on visual cues only for G1 (too many exclamation marks!!!, bright flashing colors, pictures of money/prizes)

issues.issue: MFA concept with 'two locks on a door' analogy is introduced but Grade 3 students haven't learned about authentication flows yet
issues.recommendation: Ensure prerequisite understanding of login process exists. Current deps don't establish this foundation.

issues.issue: SQL injection and man-in-the-middle attacks are too advanced for Grade 6 understanding without database/networking knowledge
issues.recommendation: Move SQL injection to G7-G8, keep Grade 6 focused on malware, phishing, and DoS

issues.issue: GOOD - Uses illustrated cards and physical bins (picture-based, unplugged)
issues.recommendation: No change needed - exemplary K skill

issues.issue: GOOD - Uses audio narration with scenario stories (appropriate for non-readers)
issues.recommendation: No change needed

issues.issue: GOOD - Uses visual representations of passwords
issues.recommendation: Simplify visuals as noted above, but concept is appropriate

issues.issue: GOOD - Picture cards with sorting activity (unplugged)
issues.recommendation: No change needed

issues.issue: GOOD - Categorization activity can be done with pictures/cards
issues.recommendation: No change needed

issues.issue: GOOD - Illustrated scenarios with audio narration and visual cues
issues.recommendation: No change needed

issues.issue: BORDERLINE - Requires sentence completion which may be too text-heavy for early G1
issues.recommendation: Add picture support: show scenarios as images where students point to consequences

issues.issue: GOOD - Visual 'cartoon pop-ups' with labeling activity
issues.recommendation: Ensure pop-ups are highly visual with minimal text

issues.issue: ACCEPTABLE - Uses template/guided activity but involves creating actual password (may need parent/teacher support)
issues.recommendation: Ensure this is scaffolded activity, not independent work

issues.issue: GOOD - Uses picture instructions (unplugged procedural activity)
issues.recommendation: No change needed

issues.issue: BORDERLINE - Discusses abstract concepts (kindness, uncomfortable situations)
issues.recommendation: Add visual scenarios/comic strips showing situations

issues.issue: CONCERN - 'List practices' requires writing/text generation which may be challenging for G2
issues.recommendation: Convert to matching activity: match pictures of good practices to their reasons

issues.issue: GOOD - Teacher-led scenarios with visual demonstrations
issues.recommendation: No change needed

issues.issue: Introduces MFA but no prior skill establishes understanding of basic authentication/login process
issues.recommendation: Add T32.G2.06 - 'Explain purpose of usernames and passwords' to establish foundation

issues.issue: Uses CreatiCode sharing settings but no dependency on basic CreatiCode project creation
issues.recommendation: Add dependency on T01.G3.02 or similar CreatiCode fundamentals

issues.issue: Depends on T09.G3.01.04 (Display variable value) which is unrelated to backups - odd dependency
issues.recommendation: Remove T09.G3.01.04 dependency. Add dependency on T01 CreatiCode project skills instead

issues.issue: Implements password masking and login flows but no prior UI design skills in T32
issues.recommendation: Dependency on T16.G3.01 is correct, but consider adding T16.G4/G5 skills for more advanced UI

issues.issue: Depends on T06.G5.01 (event patterns) which is unrelated to encryption
issues.recommendation: Remove T06.G5.01 dependency - not relevant to cipher implementation

issues.issue: Depends on T07.G5.01 (counted repeat loop) but description doesn't show loops being used
issues.recommendation: Clarify why loop dependency exists or remove it

issues.issue: Students 'read an age-appropriate article' - no specifics on article type, format, or activity structure
issues.recommendation: Specify: 'Students read a teacher-curated 2-3 paragraph summary of a data breach incident (e.g., account passwords leaked from gaming site)'

issues.issue: 'Simplified, teacher-reviewed summaries' is vague - unclear what students actually do
issues.recommendation: Provide clearer scaffolding: 'Students use a comparison template with categories: Data Collected, Data Use, Third-Party Sharing, User Rights'

issues.issue: Says 'alphabet substitution (A→D, B→E, etc.)' which is actually a shift cipher, not general substitution
issues.recommendation: Clarify: 'Using a Caesar shift cipher (shift by 3: A→D, B→E, C→F)' for accuracy

issues.issue: 'Simplified bug bounty reports' - unclear what simplification means or where reports come from
issues.recommendation: Specify source and format: 'Students read teacher-adapted bug bounty stories (1-page summaries from HackerOne/Bugcrowd)'

issues.issue: 'Teacher-provided or built in CreatiCode' - inconsistent, should specify which
issues.recommendation: If CreatiCode implementation exists, specify blocks. Otherwise, state 'teacher-provided calculator spreadsheet'

issues.issue: 'Example scenario: School chatbot gives harmful advice' - only one example given, needs more structure
issues.recommendation: Add: 'Students choose from 3 scenarios: (1) Chatbot harmful advice, (2) Image generator creates inappropriate content, (3) Perception system falsely identifies student'

issues.issue: Both cover MFA/2FA concept - G3.01 introduces with analogies, G4.04 explains prevention
issues.recommendation: Acceptable progression, but clarify distinction: G3.01='What is MFA', G4.04='Why MFA prevents attacks'. Ensure G4.04 adds substantive new content.

issues.issue: G1.04 covers scam pop-ups, G3.04 covers phishing messages - some overlap in 'spotting scams'
issues.recommendation: Acceptable - G1.04 is visual/simple, G3.04 uses checklist and is more systematic. Clarify G1.04 is 'obvious visual scams' vs G3.04 'deceptive text messages'

issues.issue: Both cover identifying what's safe to share - significant overlap
issues.recommendation: Acceptable grade progression: GK uses simple categories (favorite color vs address), G1 introduces PII terminology and more examples. Could add to GK.01: 'introduce concept' and G1.01: 'name and categorize PII systematically'

issues.issue: Could be combined - identifying PII and redacting it are closely related
issues.recommendation: Keep separate for clear learning progression, but ensure G5.03.01 focuses on identification/categorization and G5.03.02 focuses on techniques

issues.issue: Three-part sequence (G5.03.01→G5.03.02, G5.03.01→G5.03.03) but G5.03.02 and G5.03.03 don't reference each other
issues.recommendation: Add dependency: T32.G5.03.03 should depend on G5.03.02 (understand redaction before implementing consent). Sequence: identify PII → redact → understand consent

issues.issue: G7.04.02 depends on G7.04.01 (same grade, part of sequence)
issues.recommendation: Acceptable - clear progression from facial recognition to emotion detection

issues.issue: G2 ends with basic password creation and device care. G3 jumps to MFA and website safety indicators. No intermediate skills on recognizing secure websites or understanding account security basics.
issues.recommendation: Add G2.06 - 'Recognize when websites ask for personal information' and G3.00 - 'Identify parts of a URL (domain name, path)' to bridge gap

issues.issue: G4 covers data breaches and 2FA. G5 jumps to social engineering tactics. Missing bridge on basic security awareness.
issues.recommendation: Consider adding G4.05 - 'Recognize common security threats in daily digital activities' to connect breach awareness to threat identification

issues.issue: G5 ends with encryption concepts (unplugged). G6 starts with categorizing cyber attacks. Gap in applying encryption understanding to practical scenarios.
issues.recommendation: Add G6.00 - 'Identify where encryption is used in everyday tools (HTTPS, messaging apps, device storage)' before attack categorization

issues.issue: G6 covers attacks, login flows, and simple ciphers. G7 implements Caesar cipher and password cracking. Missing intermediate coding/string manipulation skills specific to security.
issues.recommendation: Ensure T10 (string manipulation) skills are mastered before G7. Dependencies already reference T10.G5.01 which is appropriate.

issues.issue: Depends on T22.G5.02, T21.G5.02 (AI topics) - creates tight coupling between AI and security topics
issues.recommendation: PRESERVE these dependencies (cross-topic are allowed), but note that students must complete AI projects before this security review. Consider making this an optional/enrichment skill if AI topics aren't completed.

issues.issue: Depends on T09.G3.01.04 (variable monitor) which seems unrelated to file backup
issues.recommendation: Remove this dependency - displaying variables is unrelated to downloading/uploading project files

issues.issue: Requires T07, T08, T09, T10, T16 skills - high cross-topic complexity
issues.recommendation: Acceptable - secure login requires loops, conditionals, variables, strings, and UI. These are fundamental skills. PRESERVE dependencies.

issues.issue: Depends on T21.G6.02, T22.G6.01, T23.G5.01 - requires extensive AI topic completion
issues.recommendation: PRESERVE but consider making this enrichment/optional. Label as 'AI Integration Skill' in curriculum guides.

issues.issue: Depends on T06.G5.01 (event patterns) - unclear why events are needed for cipher
issues.recommendation: Remove T06.G5.01 dependency unless cipher uses events (description doesn't indicate this)

issues.issue: Depend on T23.G6.01 and T23.G6.02 (perception) - appropriate but creates sequencing constraint
issues.recommendation: PRESERVE - analyzing ethics of facial recognition requires understanding the technology. Mark as 'Requires T23 completion'

issues.issue: Depends on T21.G6.04, T22.G6.04, T23.G6.03, T24.G6.01 - requires all AI topics through grade 6
issues.recommendation: PRESERVE but make this a capstone/summative project. Too many dependencies for regular skill.

issues.issue: Covers both 'unkind messages' (cyberbullying) and 'uncomfortable situations' (safety) in one skill
issues.recommendation: Consider splitting into G2.03a (respond to unkind behavior) and G2.03b (recognize uncomfortable/unsafe situations)

issues.issue: Covers three core areas of digital citizenship - could be more focused
issues.recommendation: Acceptable as overview skill, but could follow up with separate skills for each area in G5

issues.issue: Penetration testing checklist is provided but not detailed in description
issues.recommendation: Expand description to list specific test cases or reference where checklist is documented

issues.issue: G3.01 uses 'MFA', G4.04 uses '2FA' - inconsistent terminology
issues.recommendation: Use 'MFA' consistently, or note that '2FA is a type of MFA' in G4.04

issues.issue: G5.06 says 'encryption', but G6.05/G7.01 correctly identify as 'cipher' - encryption is broader term
issues.recommendation: G5.06 should say 'encryption scrambles messages using ciphers' to be more precise

issues.issue: Uses 'PII' acronym which may not be introduced yet
issues.recommendation: Spell out on first use: 'Personally Identifiable Information (PII)'

issues.issue: Lists four specific examples - could be generalized for flexibility
issues.recommendation: Add 'such as' before examples to indicate these are samples, not exhaustive list

issues.issue: Says 'teacher-provided screenshots' - could students capture their own?
issues.recommendation: For safety, keep as teacher-provided, but note this in G4+ students could find examples with supervision

issues.issue: Lists specific blocks (letter, join, unicode) - good! But could reference official block names
issues.recommendation: Verify block names match CreatiCode exactly and add category (e.g., 'from Operators palette')

issues.issue: States 'NOT built-in encryption' - good clarification but could explain why
issues.recommendation: Add: 'using string manipulation blocks (NOT built-in encryption blocks) to understand how ciphers work internally'

missing_skills.skill: Explain purpose of usernames and passwords
missing_skills.description: Students learn that usernames identify who you are and passwords prove it's really you. They compare to name tags (public) and secret handshakes (private). They practice creating appropriate usernames that don't reveal personal information.
missing_skills.rationale: Foundation needed before G3.01 introduces MFA. Currently jumps from 'passwords keep things safe' (GK.03) to 'MFA uses two locks' (G3.01) without explaining login process.

missing_skills.skill: Recognize security indicators in apps and games
missing_skills.description: Students identify security features in apps they use: login screens, privacy settings, parental controls, report buttons. They explain why each feature helps keep them safe and when to use each one.
missing_skills.rationale: Bridges G4 concepts (data breaches, MFA) to G5 social engineering by applying security awareness to familiar apps

missing_skills.skill: Understand difference between privacy and security
missing_skills.description: Students distinguish between privacy (controlling who sees your data) and security (protecting data from unauthorized access). They analyze scenarios where privacy is violated without security breach (friend shares your photo) and security is breached affecting privacy (hacker steals passwords).
missing_skills.rationale: Critical distinction not explicitly taught. Students mix up 'private' and 'secure' throughout K-8

missing_skills.skill: Identify where encryption is used in everyday digital life
missing_skills.description: Building on G5.06 encryption concepts, students identify real-world uses: HTTPS websites (padlock icon), encrypted messaging apps (WhatsApp, Signal), device encryption (phone lock screen), encrypted backups. They explain what data each protects and when it's encrypted.
missing_skills.rationale: Bridge between unplugged cipher activity (G5.06) and implementing ciphers (G6.05). Students need to see real applications.

missing_skills.description: Students learn why public Wi-Fi is risky (unencrypted, man-in-the-middle attacks possible). They identify safe practices: avoid banking/passwords on public Wi-Fi, verify network name with staff, use VPN if available. They compare encrypted (secure) vs unencrypted (open) networks.
missing_skills.rationale: Common real-world scenario not covered. Relevant to middle school students using devices outside home/school.

missing_skills.description: Students learn that AI can generate fake images, videos, and audio that look/sound real. They examine examples and identify telltale signs (unnatural movements, wrong shadows, context clues). They discuss why verifying sources matters and how deepfakes can be misused.
missing_skills.rationale: Increasingly important with AI advancement. Connects to T21 (image generation) and T22 (text generation).

missing_skills.skill: Understand ransomware and data hostage scenarios
missing_skills.description: Students learn how ransomware encrypts files and demands payment. They analyze prevention (backups, software updates, email caution) and response (never pay, restore from backup, report to authorities). They create backup and response plans for hypothetical ransomware attack on school project.
missing_skills.rationale: Major modern threat not explicitly covered. G6.01 mentions 'ransomware' briefly but doesn't explain.

missing_skills.description: Students identify Internet of Things (IoT) devices (smart speakers, cameras, thermostats) and their security risks: default passwords, unencrypted data transmission, always-listening microphones. They list security checklist: change default passwords, update firmware, understand what data is collected.
missing_skills.rationale: IoT security is increasingly relevant but not covered in current progression

missing_skills.skill: Identify parts of a URL and email address
missing_skills.description: Students learn to read URLs (protocol, domain, path) and email addresses (username, @ symbol, domain). They practice identifying suspicious URLs (misspellings, wrong domains like googlle.com) and email addresses (random letters, suspicious domains).
missing_skills.rationale: Foundation needed before G3.02 (website safety indicators) and G3.04 (phishing). Currently assumes URL literacy.

missing_skills.skill: Practice safe searching and website evaluation
missing_skills.description: Students learn to use kid-safe search engines and evaluate website credibility: check About page, verify author, look for ads vs content, identify sponsored results. They compare trustworthy sites (official .gov, .edu) to questionable sites.
missing_skills.rationale: Practical skill gap - students are searching online but not explicitly taught evaluation skills in security context

missing_skills.skill: Understand software updates and patch management
missing_skills.description: Students learn why software updates are important: fix security vulnerabilities, add new features, improve performance. They identify when to update (notifications, regular schedule) and practice checking for updates on classroom devices. They discuss why delaying updates increases risk.
missing_skills.rationale: Critical security practice not taught. Students often dismiss update notifications without understanding importance.

missing_skills.description: Students learn safe file-sharing practices: use school-approved platforms, check sharing permissions before sending, verify recipient before sharing sensitive files, use expiring links when available. They configure sharing settings in classroom tools (Google Drive, OneDrive) and explain why public links can be risky.
missing_skills.rationale: Students share files constantly but security aspects aren't explicitly taught. Builds on T32.G3.03 CreatiCode sharing.

missing_skills.description: Students distinguish between conflict and cyberbullying (repeated, intentional harm using digital tools). They learn response strategies: don't respond, save evidence (screenshot), block sender, report to trusted adult/platform. They role-play bystander intervention (support victim, report) and discuss why silent witnesses enable bullying.
missing_skills.rationale: G2.03 introduces 'unkind messages' but doesn't cover systematic cyberbullying. Grade 7 students need more sophisticated understanding.

skills.feature: CreatiCode sharing panel and privacy settings
skills.verification_needed: Verify that CreatiCode has: (1) Project privacy settings (private/class/public), (2) Ability to invite specific users, (3) Permission verification
Verify that CreatiCode allows: (1) Downloading project as file, (2) Re-uploading saved project, (3) File format preservation

skills.feature: String manipulation blocks for password validation
skills.verification_needed: Verify: (1) 'length of [string]' block exists, (2) Password masking is possible (or needs workaround), (3) Button state control exists, (4) Variables can count failed attempts

skills.feature: String manipulation blocks for cipher implementation
skills.verification_needed: Verify all four blocks exist in CreatiCode with exact names/functionality described
Verify: (1) T12.G5.01 table blocks exist, (2) Timestamp can be generated/stored, (3) Tables can be protected/made read-only
Verify: (1) Variables can store user roles, (2) Conditional blocks can control access, (3) UI elements can be shown/hidden based on conditions
Verify T16 UI widgets support: (1) Password input type or text masking, (2) Button enable/disable states, (3) Dynamic text updates
Can CreatiCode blur regions of images? Or does this need external tool? Description says 'image blurring techniques'
skills.alternative: If not available in CreatiCode, change to 'use external image editor to blur faces before uploading to project'

skills.verification_needed: Description says 'teacher-provided OR built in CreatiCode' - clarify which. If built in CreatiCode, specify blocks/implementation.
skills.recommendation: Change to 'teacher-provided calculator' unless CreatiCode implementation exists

phase_1_critical_fixes: Fix X-2 rule violations in T32.G4.01, G4.02, G5.03.01
Split T32.G6.01 into 4 separate skills (malware, phishing, network attacks, database attacks)
Verify CreatiCode string manipulation blocks (G6.05, G7.01) - CRITICAL for implementation
Add missing foundation skill T32.G2.06 (username/password purpose)
Simplify T32.GK.03 password visuals for kindergarten appropriateness
phase_2_quality_improvements: Split T32.G5.01 into digital and physical social engineering
Add missing scaffolding skills (G3.00 URL parts, G4.00 safe searching, G4.05 security indicators)
Clarify vague descriptions (G4.03 articles, G5.02 privacy policies, G6.04 bug bounty reports)
Verify CreatiCode project sharing features (G3.03) and backup capabilities (G5.04)
phase_3_gap_filling: Add modern security topics: deepfakes (G6.07), public Wi-Fi (G7.05), ransomware (G8.05), IoT security (G7.06)
Add missing foundational concepts: privacy vs security (G5.07), software updates (G5.08), secure file sharing (G6.08)
Improve K-2 skills with more visual/hands-on activities (G1.03, G2.03, G2.04)
phase_4_polish: Standardize terminology (MFA vs 2FA, encryption vs cipher)
Add 'such as' to example lists for flexibility
Verify all cross-topic dependencies are essential and document why
Create teacher notes for skills requiring external resources (articles, videos, calculators)
Label AI-dependent skills as enrichment/optional for flexible sequencing
